title: 104_hr3998
content: The "Citizen Debt Reduction Contribution Act" includes provisions for citizens to donate income tax refunds, social security benefits, military retirement benefits, and veterans' disability compensation to reduce the Federal deficit. Congress acknowledges the contributions of citizens and aims to use budget savings from the Act to decrease Government spending. The "Citizen Debt Reduction Contribution Act" allows citizens to designate income tax overpayments to reduce the public debt under Sec. 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxpayers can designate a portion of their tax overpayment to reduce the public debt of the United States. The designation must be made at the time of filing the tax return and will be treated as a refund to the taxpayer. Taxpayers can designate a portion of their tax overpayment to reduce the public debt of the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer designated amounts to a special account for deficit reduction. Taxpayers can designate income tax overpayments to reduce public debt. Amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 1995. Donation of Social Security benefits can also reduce the federal deficit. The Social Security Act is amended to allow recipients of monthly insurance benefits to elect to transfer a portion of their benefits to the Treasury as a gift to reduce the public debt. The Social Security Act allows recipients of monthly insurance benefits to elect to transfer a portion of their benefits to the Treasury as a gift to reduce the public debt. Amounts subject to this election are not taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, and no deductions are allowed for these amounts. SEC. 5. Donation of military retirement benefits to reduce federal deficit. Chapter 71 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to allow members or former members of the armed forces to donate a portion of their retired or retainer pay to the Treasury as a gift to reduce the public debt. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to accept these donations. The amendment allows military members to donate part of their pay to reduce public debt. The donated amounts are not taxable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No deductions are allowed for amounts not included in gross income. Veterans can donate disability compensation to reduce the federal deficit. The amendment allows veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. The Secretary will withhold the designated amount and transfer it to the Treasury as a gift. The donated amounts are not taxable income. The amendment allows veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. The donated amounts are not taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No deduction is allowed for amounts not included in gross income. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. The amendment allows veterans to donate a portion of their compensation to reduce the public debt. Savings resulting from this Act will not be considered for budget estimates under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
